A: You can convert a String to byte[] in Java using the getBytes() method of the String class. Here is an example:

```java
String str = "Hello, World!";
byte[] bytes = str.getBytes();
```

In this example, the getBytes() method is used without any parameters, which means it uses the platform's default charset to encode the String. If you want to use a specific charset, you can pass it as a parameter to the getBytes() method. For example, to use UTF-8 encoding:

```java
String str = "Hello, World!";
byte[] bytes = str.getBytes(StandardCharsets.UTF_8);
```

In both examples, the byte[] variable 'bytes' will contain the byte representation of the String 'str'.

A: You can use the following code to convert a String to byte array:

```java
String str = "Hello, World!";
byte[] bytes = str.getBytes();
```

In this code, the getBytes() method is used to convert the String to a byte array. The resulting byte array will contain the binary representation of the String.

Please note that the getBytes() method without any parameters uses the platform's default charset to encode the String. If you want to use a specific charset, you can pass it as a parameter to the getBytes() method. For example, to use UTF-8 encoding:

```java
String str = "Hello, World!";
byte[] bytes = str.getBytes(StandardCharsets.UTF_8);
```

In both examples, the byte[] variable 'bytes' will contain the byte representation of the String 'str'.
